title: Why Grayscale's $35B IPO Could Tank Your Portfolio in 2026

transcript.text:
The largest digital asset platform in the world 
is finally going public. We're not calling it

crypto anymore or crapto. They're called 
Digital Assets. This company's the market

leader in every key market they operate in 
and we really like leaders. The company's

called Grayscale. However, there's some 
major problems with their IPO that half,

okay, all degenerates don't see coming. 
And if you dabble in crypto funds,

you're thinking about investing in some 
crypto ETFs, then this video is a mustwatch.

How to analyze any IPO? Well, typically, 
IPOs represent growth companies, so they

better have meaningful revenue growth. That's 
not optional. We want to look at who their key

competitors are. What leadership position do they 
have? Maybe there are better options for similar

exposure elsewhere. How big is the opportunity? 
Well, Grayscale says this is a $365 billion

opportunity. That's certainly big enough. Most 
importantly, how does a company make money? What

would you say you do here? This tells us what 
exposure we're getting. This is something that

professional investors focus heavily on while 
a lot of retail investors don't. So, I like

this market map that Grayscale put together. They 
call it mapping the digital asset universe. Now,

when you look at the top there, under currencies 
and smart contract platforms, I like how they

differentiate Bitcoin and Ethereum by these terms, 
that makes up 70% of the entire crypto market,

those two coins. And I think you need to be 
careful here, when you start talking about

tokenization. So, let's say you start to tokenize 
assets. Well, you don't want a double count there,

right? Just because you tokenized $5 billion 
in real estate doesn't mean that the value

of the entire crypto universe went up by $5 
billion. And then under consumer and culture

here you have what we call crapto, especially 
this pumped-up fun platform. I recently saw a

piece where somebody was bragging how it's never 
been easier to print money by doing rug poles on

the platform. The fact that that sort of thing is 
just allowed seems ludicrous to me. But anyway,

when we start scrolling down the Grayscale -S1, 
we come quickly to this section. They talk about

their products, ETPs and ETFs. So, basically, 
funds. They have both passive and active around

$34 billion worth. So we want to put that number 
into perspective. It sounds a lot on paper,

but it's only about 1% of the total $3.3 trillion 
crypto market. And that market just so happens to

be about 2.6% of the total equities market. So, 
Grayscale manages some ETFs, and here you can

see they're actually pretty formidable. They're 
the 22nd largest ETF provider. They're hanging

around popular names like ProShares, Wisdom Tree, 
Global X. So, they've fared quite well in terms of

the amount of assets they've attracted and they 
also offer some private funds. So, when it comes

down to it, they manage about $35 billion worth 
of digital assets. Now, at a 1% expense ratio,

that means their revenues should be around $350 
million. Well, when we look at revenues, we find

something interesting here. They're actually a lot 
more. But, first of all, this revenue decline from

2023 to 2024 is quite concerning. We'd wonder if 
they're exposed to some degen volatility there.

But what stands out immediately is that this 
is an extremely profitable business. So those

numbers you see there that I've highlighted, those 
aren't gross margins. Those would be attractive

if they were. These are operating margins. So 
this company's printing money. And I love this,

the letter in their S-1 from the founder. He talks 
about money printer go burr. And he's talking

about the economy. We should be talking about 
his platform. And whenever you have a situation

where somebody's printing money, it attracts 
competitors like mad, sharks in a blue ocean. Now,

when we keep scrolling through the S-1, we 
come across perhaps the most pertinent piece

of information that you'll find, which is the 
weighted average management fee. Remember that

we speculated that if it was 1%, they'd be 
making $350 million. Well, it's actually a

lot more than that. And you can see here in 2023, 
it was actually upwards of 2%. And most recently,

in the first nine months of this year, it's 
floated down to around 1.4%. And the first

thing you'll note here is that this average fee 
has declined significantly over the past several

years. And if we just took their assets under 
management, multiplied it by this average fee,

then we can project what their revenues might 
be. We can compare those to actuals. And look,

it's spot-on. So this is a very easy business 
to follow, right? The assets under management

multiplied by their expense ratio gives you their 
revenues. And this is where things start to become

problematic. So when we look at their assets under 
management, 70% of those are found in two ETFs,

the Grayscale Bitcoin Trust ETF and the Grayscale 
Ethereum Trust ETF, 88% of their revenues come

from these two ETFs. And what you need to remember 
here is that the size of these ETFs is going to

depend on two things. First, the price of the 
underlying asset. So in this case, the price

of Bitcoin and Ethereum, plus the inflows and 
outflows. So investors have been pulling money

out of these ETFs presumably because their fees 
are atrocious. And when you look at outflows last

year, they had $25 billion in outflows. That's 
not good at all. Essentially, you're losing market

share. In the first nine months of this year, they 
had another $3.5 billion in outflows. This is very

problematic. It's very concerning. And when you 
look at the largest crypto ETFs out there, we've

pulled up this list from Vetify. You can see where 
these two ETFs sit. Oh, look at the top there.

iShares Bitcoin Trust. So, they're absolutely 
dominating this space. When Bitcoin ETFs first

came out, we did an analysis on them and looked 
at all the players. ARK was in there. Well, now

it looks like we indeed have a winner in iShares. 
That's no surprise at all. BlackRock dominating,

as usual. Now, when it comes to fund investing for 
degenerates, the beginner level is "muh portfolio

needs this ETF cuz Tom Lee said I should invest in 
it." These people usually buy high and sell low.

Then there's the DGEN that eventually realizes 
that the asset that they're holding ought to

reflect the value of its contents. This idea of 
net asset value. That's when a basic understanding

of NAV happens. So, then, you'll see people make 
excuses as to why a fund ought to trade above NAV.

It never should. If it does, then just go buy the 
underlying asset. It's silly, right? That happens

because of hype and because of idiots. {you just 
blowing from stupid town.} And then you need

to start asking, well, how much are you paying 
the owners of this vehicle to provide you this

exposure? This is not really something DGens has 
started questioning yet. They haven't gotten that

far, but institutions certainly are. And that's 
where we can pull up this same list of crypto

ETFs and start looking at fees. Wow, is this 
telling? So, look at how expensive the Grayscale

offerings are compared to the competition. 
This is a big problem. And they're not going

to be able to sustain their AUM. They're going to 
keep seeing outflows unless they drop their fees,

which is going to impact revenues, which is why 
you have essentially flatlined revenues. So,

just to summarize here, Grayscale is printing 
money simply by managing money. Their fees,

while declining over time significantly, are 
still very, very expensive. Nothing's going

to stop large ETF providers like BlackRock from 
undercutting them on price. They could even use

these vehicles as loss leaders, frankly, to 
attract institutions. I would go so far as to

say nothing justifies these expense ratio premiums 
that we're seeing. I'd challenge people to put up

some evidence otherwise. Why should investors be 
paying so much for these funds? They shouldn't.

But most importantly, the problem here is going 
back to our initial set of screening criteria

for IPOs, their revenues appear to be flatlining. 
Frankly, even declining. So if you look at 2023,

2024, and a 2025 estimate we've provided here 
based on that $35 billion in AUM they claim

against the 1.39% expense ratio, you see they're 
going to be declining this year as well. Now, if

you go into their S-1, I like how they point out 
the risks. They do a very good job of highlighting

the many problems in the crypto space. They 
talk about how, from 2021 to 2023, the entire

value of crypto dropped 62%. They point to all the 
major crypto companies that ended up liquidating.

In some cases, fraud was involved. The amount of 
fraud in this space is just incredible to believe.

And then they talk about this recent cascade of 
forced liquidation. So approximately $20 billion

in leveraged positions were liquidated following 
a sudden drop in Bitcoin and Ethereum prices. And

look, here's the sudden drop, a massive crash, 
right? So, if there's ever actually any real

significant volatility in the crypto space, then 
I guess, then people are just absolutely toast

because they're not managing risk appropriately 
in probably what is, if you can call it an asset

class, one of the most riskiest asset classes 
I've ever seen. So, when it comes to people that

are looking at this company, I don't know what 
will happen to the stock once the IPO happens,

but we can certainly take a poke at valuation. 
So, let's use those predicted 2025 revenues of

$487 million. What we can then do is start looking 
at various levels of price to sales and, sort of,

predicting a market cap. Now, for those of you who 
follow our own internal simple valuation ratio,

which is market cap divided by annualized 
revenues, price to sales isn't much different.

And since we don't have last quarter's revenues, 
we can just use 2025 predicted at a price to sales

of three. They'd have a $ 1.5 billion market 
cap. An average price to sales would probably

be around seven. That gives them a market cap 
of 3.4 billion. You double that, you get to 6.8.

And anything above $10 billion would be too rich. 
Well, guess what? Industry analysts are projecting

potential valuations of $30-33 billion. So, way 
overpriced. Now it's going to trade under the

ticker GRAY for those of you that are interested. 
We always get the lazy DGEN leaving the "this aged

well' comment. One of my insightful contributions 
to humanity. The reality is that nobody knows how

this stock is going to react at IPO time. The 
fintwats are likely going to hype this up for

no good reason. And what will end up happening 
is a lot of people decide to play musical chairs

with this momentum stock if it turns out to be 
one. And that's a very bad idea. You always want

to focus on the company that you're investing in. 
Think about two things here. What exposure are you

looking for when you invest in Grayscale? Let's 
assume digital assets cuz that's the exposure

you're getting, right? Largely exposure to Bitcoin 
and Ethereum ETFs. Are there better ways to get

that exposure? Yes, there are. You could just buy 
Bitcoin and Ethereum, for one. But Coinbase might

be a better pick-and-shovel play because they have 
diversified revenue streams. Again, if you want

exposure to the two mechanisms that dictate most 
the success of Grayscale as it lives today, then

invest in Bitcoin and Ethereum. Now, if you want 
greater exposure to crypto as an asset class, we

did this really cool piece that looks at how you 
can build your own crypto ETF and not pay these

extravagant fees. Give that a watch next. Thanks 
so much for taking the time to watch this today.
